name: Sheltered
description: Sheltered is a deep and emotional survival management game. You take on the role of protecting four family members who, after a global apocalypse, have found their way to a deserted shelter.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: Dual Core CPU Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: GeForce 7800, AMD HD 4600, Intel HD Graphics 3000 or above DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 600 MB available space Sound Card: Windows Compatible Card Additional Notes: Note: In some instances, systems may require model specific drivers. If your system manufacturers no longer support hardware under this category, it may not be possible to run this title. Should this be the case, we are unable to assist you and recommend that you pursue support from your respective system manufacturer.

reviews.review_text: Simple and addictive, but also repetive if you play it 12 hours straight.  You play as a leader of a family of four and you control each member to scavenge, fight, or manage around you base. You can expand your community by recruiting new members and build a bigger shelter. You weapons will also advance from sticks and pipes, to crowbars and knives, and eventually gun. At some point your characters may die, and it may create emotional impact on you, but there is no time to mourn but harvest the body and put the meat in the fridge.  Also, enemies can raid your base, and this is the part where I really dislike the game. You can't arm your members with weapons when you get raided so the fights are quite one sided. You can arm traps that are built inside your base, but you can only start arming when the raid started. Aside from that, the shelter is already cramped with all the other items so traps are just gonna make the shelter even more disorangized. Also, there was no instructions on how to arm traps and I spent 10 mins watching my shelter get rekt wondering when I can't arm a shotgun trap when I have ammo (Turns out I need to craft a trip wire too in order to arm the trap).  It is still a good game though, ate 15 hours straight from me and I am likely to replay it again. This time rushing for police stations and getting all the guns so I can start murdering survivors.  Pros: -Simple gameplay, low complexity but high depth. -Customized characters that you grow attach to. -Crafting, with a large amount of items and materials to fiddle with -Low graphic entry. -Base building.  Cons: -Half-♥♥♥♥♥ tutorial, quite misleading at late game.  Overall: A total recommend from me. Though I do find it dull when you start rushing the speed up button to get your survivors finish scavenging, it does get fun when you add some narrative in there by doing some role playing.

Having only merely scratched the surface of this game in my 10+ hours of gameplay, I can safely say I'm liking what I've played so far, with still so much more to explore.  This isn't a game that hands you all you need on a silver platter right out the gates. You're going to have to really scavenge and prioritize and use time management properly. You start out with a tiny shelter with limited supplies, and it becomes apparent very quickly that you're going to need to remedy your water and food issue rather fast, and fuel as well, because if your generator goes down, everything living in your shelter soon will as well.  The game offers a basic tutorial at the start which is enough to familiarize yourself with the game and controls, after that, it's all up to you. You can allow new recruits to join, some will become loyal, others will take off and may sabotage your air or water filtration system (bad personal experience in-game lol). I always enjoy a well-made survival game, and this one is really up there for me for really offering what I need in a survival game, and that's an actual challenge with longevity.

This game has potential. I bought this game 1 year ago and since then the devs have been working on it and regularly adding new content. I remember the times when I had to open and close the door for each member of the shelter, where we did not have proper short-cuts, broken notifications etc. Its good to see we no longer have that type of annoyances for new players. I won't give detailed analysis of the game. The summary of the game is; scavenge, develop your shelter and survive. Its fun... FOR A WHILE.  The major issue of the game is once you get the basics it becomes very repetetive. The game 'still' does not have any re-playability. Once you learn how to prioritize what to craft, when and what to scavenge you won't have any difficulty dealing with the environment.  Everytime a major patch arrives, I start to a new game to see it will make me struggle and the answers is always a big Nope. Every 100 days later I have all my parts upgraded to max, tier 4-5 everything, enough food and water to keep 5-6 people alive for the next 100 days. This happens after each patch again and again.   I do not think the solution is making the game more difficult but rather expanding the possibilities.  I recommend buying this game when its on sale, however dont expect much replayability since the game is very limited in that sense.

Brutally hard at first, but once you get a stable shelter going, it starts to drag and get tedious. I am seeing hints of some sort of end-game though. I really hope this is not all there is. When it comes to simulation games, there are two kinds of player; macromanagers and micromanagers. The former prefers to make generalized decisions and allow the specific details to be handled within the ai. The latter prefers to manage every detail of the process, and their gameplay is a collection of their smaller choices aggregated. Macromanagers for instance leave free will on when playing THE SIMS whereas micromanagers turn it off or override it often. SHELTERED is a game for the micromanagers. I am not one of those.  While the premise and depth is great and I can tell the execution here is good, the biggest flaw I found was a lack of AI in the family members. They won't do any task unless commanded. Mom will happily stand outside dying of radiation poisoning while standing next to the damaged air filter with no hazmat suit on, and will make no effort at all to put on said rad suit and fix the filter unless specifically commanded. This is true of everyonr; you must issue commands to get people to do anything, and they won't grab a gas mask or rad suit unless you walk them through the steps of doing so each time they go outaide. This sort of play got old with me quickly, but a micromanager would likely love it. 6/10 but not for all gamers.

For the first few hours/in game days, the game is quite challenging. There are risks you take with sending out a scavenging party when you are running low of water or when you haven't added people to your bunker. Do you build a larger fridge or a bulletproof vest? Do you run the risk of food poisoning because you are low on water to maintain hygiene?   But once you get past the early game, the game rapidly becomes monotonous. Between the micromanaging of your survivor's needs and constant repair of all the things, the poor balance of combat and NPC interactions only highlights the lack of mid/end game balance. Its a fairly interesting game but feels like it never quite left early access. Wait for a sale to buy.

Similar to some other commends, while this game could possibly be enjoyable if you like tedious, repetitive gameplay, the game has too much emphasis on the basics of building things to make sure your family doesn't die, and fixing stuff that breaks constantly. While raiders start attacking your base after you have built the skeleton of your base, the dull and almost annoying tasks of having to manage your base overwhelm any desire to keep playing to this stage.   I think in theory if the game's UI and management system made simple tasks a lot more streamlined (responding to distress signals, anyone?) the game would suddenly become a lot more enjoyable. However, considering this feedback was given during Early Access and little to no work has been done on this now that it has released, I have doubts that the developers are planning on implementing anything like this in the future.  My opinion is to wait for an exceptionally good Steam Sale.

This game is amazing, but there are still a few game breaking bugs in version 1.4. If it were any other game, this would not be a problem. You could just reload from your last save and try again until the game doesn't encounter a bug. With Sheltered, there is no save function, so it's a deal breaker. (Note: if your family has a dog, do not try to send it out on an expedition before the dog has properly returned from the previous expedition. Doing this breaks the game, and you will permanently lose two family members through glitch.)  The second sin the game commits is making you design your family from scratch at the start of every session. So if you die, you must select your hair colour again. On the one hand, I see the point of this. By making the first five minutes of the game very tedious, you disincentivize people from restarting the game at every minor hiccup, making the hiccups in the game feel scarier and more threatening. However, designing the starter family is the most tedious part of the game. I don't mind building the shelter's first shower and toilet over and over and over and over every time I start a new game, but modelling the game family to look like my actual family every time has crossed the line from good-punishing to just annoying.  When the next game patch is released, I will probably rewrite this review to recommend this game. It has so much going for it, and an excellent way of spending a full day for good long session times. If you're the sort of gamer who only has half an hour to burn each day, maybe give this one a miss. Remembering where you were and what strategy you were going for gets tricky. It really was designed with the long session length in mind.  I'd love to tell you all the tricks I've learned to do well at the game, and game it by its own rules, but you're reading this because you want to know if you should buy it, not because you want strategy tips.  I will say, however, that most of the tips for winning are things that would probably work in real life also. There are a few 'WTF?' moments around the way water storage works for expeditions, but if that were handled more realistically, the game would be less fun.

It gets boring after day 30-40, when you have enough water to buy everything, and thus food/materials/etc - starts flowing from the horn of plenty.  Nobody attacks you, nothing is happening, gets boring fast.  And of course, the micromanagement thing - having to tell your guy to wipe his ♥♥♥ every time is a terrific idea the first two hundred times.   All in all, very interesting concept, but subpar implementation.

(Recieved from humble bundle)  The UI is a bother for one, some of the UI gets in the way of important things in the bunker and is tedious as well as annoying.  The RNG is also way too much of a playing element of this game to even call it a strategy game. The balance is just way off and from my experience, vital items are unreasonably rare. Another ridiculous aspect is you can't leave to look for water without water (not that I would ever find any water) all you can do is wait for it to rain and sometimes that just doesn't happen.  There is still potential though. Some of the progression seems compelling and the concept is interesting, it just doesn't work right now and I cannot reccommend it at all. This game will make you mad.  This game is not complete trash but it's worth a skip, from my experience it was just tedious and underiterated. The potential keeps this game on its feet and I hope to give it another try if the developers improve the fixable but severely damaged gameplay sheltered has to offer.  4/10
